drink.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to take liquid into your mouth and swallow it
drink.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: You should drink plenty of water.
What would you like to drink?
Take a seat while I get you something to drink.
She filled the glass and drank.
drink.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: to drink alcohol, especially regularly or too much
drink.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: He’s been drinking heavily since his wife died.
My flatmate Cherry drinks like a fish (=regularly drinks a lot of alcohol).
drink.translation[0].note_box[0].section: to drink something in a noisy way
to drink all of something very quickly
to drink all of an alcoholic drink very quickly
to drink something quickly with large mouthfuls, especially from a bottle
to make food or drink go down your throat and towards your stomach
She swallowed the bitter medicine instead of spitting it out.
drink.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: an amount of liquid that you drink, or the act of drinking something
drink.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: He took a drink of his coffee.
drink.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: He’d obviously had a few drinks.
drink.translation[1].definitions[3].defi: the habit of drinking too much alcohol, in a way that is very bad for your health
drink.translation[1].definitions[3].exam: The marriage ended because of her husband’s drink problem (=he drank too much alcohol).
They had driven him to drink (=made him start drinking too much alcohol regularly).
After her retirement from the stage she took to drink (=started drinking too much alcohol).
drink.translation[1].note_box[0].heading: – Meanings 1,2, & 3
drink.translation[1].note_box[0].section: have a drink
Let’s go and have a drink.
take a drink
He took another long drink of water.
go for a drink
Why don’t we go for a drink after work?
buy/get somebody a drink
It’s my turn to buy you a drink.
pour (somebody) a drink
She got out two glasses and poured us a drink.
make (somebody) a drink
Shall I make you a hot drink?
sip your drink
Connie was sitting at the table, sipping her drink slowly.
down your drink
He downed his drink and stood up.
a soft drink
Would you like some wine, or a soft drink?
an alcoholic drink
Beer, wine, and other alcoholic drinks will be available.
a fizzy drink
Dentists have warned that sweet fizzy drinks are bad for children’s teeth.
a hot/warm drink
Come inside and I’ll make you a hot drink.
a cool/cold drink
They were all out in the garden, sipping cool drinks.
a refreshing drink
Enjoy a refreshing drink in our lakeside café.
a stiff/strong drink
He was in need of a stiff drink to calm himself down.
a relaxing/leisurely drink
The hotel terrace is an ideal place to enjoy a relaxing drink.
a diet drink/a low-calorie drink
People are buying more and more diet drinks.
a celebratory drink
After winning the game, they went out for a celebratory drink.
drink.translation[1].note_box[1].section: ‘Would you like a drink?’ ‘Yes, I’ll have a lemonade.’
They had a few drinks in a local bar.
Can I get you something to drink?
a cold drink that does not contain alcohol, especially one that is sweet and has bubbles in it
a drink, usually of wine, that a group of people have on a special occasion, for example to celebrate something or wish someone luck in the future
At midnight they all drank a toast to the New Year.
a drink – often used on menus and signs
Beer is the most popular alcoholic beverage.
